0	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-puppet-debate-idUSKCN11W2EK	Clinton and Trump puppets face off ahead of presidential debate	"

Puppets resembling U.S. presidential candidates Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump squared off in New York City on Monday a few hours before the real candidates were due to engage in their first debate.The puppets took questions from a human moderator on such topics as climate change and women's rights. The event was performed by cast members of Avenue Q
column2: a Broadway musical starring people and puppets.""It's a hoax. It's hoax. It's fake. It's fake. You've got Bill Nye the science guy
column3: and Neil deGrasse Mike Tyson saying whatever they want
column4: puppet Trump said about climate change
column5: referring to television presenter Nye and a mash-up of astrophysicist Neil deGrasse Tyson and the former boxer Mike Tyson. ""We all know the sun is going to crash into the Earth. We know it's fine. It's huge. It's huge
column6: the Trump puppet added.

column1: When asked for their impressions of each other after their first debate
column2: puppet Clinton said
column3: ""I expected him to be crass and rude
column4: and he delivered. So I guess he delivered on his promise.""

column1: Puppet Trump said puppet Clinton ""is a two
column2: a three on a good day.""The real Clinton and Trump are scheduled to face off for the first time in a debate on Monday night
column3: six weeks before the Nov. 8 election.

1	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-mexico-idUSKCN11W2EE	Mexicans prefer Clinton to Donald Trump
column2: poll shows	"

column1: MEXICO CITY Mexicans favor U.S. Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton over Republican Donald Trump by a 10-1 ratio
column2: according to a poll.The poll
column3: conducted by Consulta Mitofsky and released last week
column4: showed that 2.9 percent of Mexicans have a favorable opinion of Trump
column5: compared to 30.4 percent for Clinton. The poll comes almost a month after a meeting between Trump and Mexican President Enrique Pena Nieto in Mexico City sparked outrage across the country and led to the resignation of Luis Videgaray as finance minister.Roy Campos
column6: director of the Mitofsky polling firm
column7: said Mexican interest in the U.S. presidential election signified a change from years past.

column1: While in the election of 2008 the interest awakened by [Democratic President Barack] Obama was based on approval ... now the interest is because of fear
column2: Campos said
column3: adding that Trump is the least popular U.S. presidential candidate among Mexicans in history.

column1: When he announced his candidacy last year
column2: Trump said Mexico was sending rapists and drug dealers to the United States and that he would build a wall on the southern U.S. border and make Mexico pay for it. He also has threatened to impose punitive tariffs on Mexico
column3: deport millions of migrants and ditch the North American Free Trade Agreement.The poll
column4: which was conducted between Sept. 2 and 5
column5: surveyed 1
column6: 000 Mexicans and had a margin of error of 3.1 percent.

column1: (Reporting by Natalie Schachar; Editing by Bill Trott)"
2	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-sept11-senate-idUSKCN11W29O	Senate sets Wednesday vote on Obama veto of Saudi September 11 bill	"
WASHINGTON The U.S. Senate will vote on Wednesday on whether to override President Barack Obama's veto of a bill allowing relatives of victims in the Sept. 11
column2: 2001 attacks to sue Saudi Arabia.The vote
column3: which Senate Republican leader Mitch McConnell set as the chamber reconvened on Monday
column4: would be the first action in an attempt by lawmakers to override Obama's Sept. 23 veto of the Justice Against Sponsors of Terrorism Act.A successful override requires support from two-thirds of lawmakers in both the Senate and House of Representatives
column5: which are controlled by Republicans.Known as JASTA
column6: the legislation passed the Senate and House in reaction to long-running suspicions
column8: that hijackers of the four U.S. jetliners that attacked the United States in 2001 were backed by the Saudi government.

column1: Fifteen of the 19 hijackers were Saudi nationals.
In vetoing the bill
column2: Obama warned that other countries could use the law as an excuse to sue U.S. diplomats
column3: members of the military or companies
column4: even for actions of foreign organizations that had received U.S. aid
column5: equipment or training.McConnell said Wednesday's vote will follow two hours of debate divided between Republicans and Democrats. No time for the vote has been set.

column1: (Reporting by David Morgan; Editing by Sandra Maler and Dan Grebler)"
3	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-poll-idUSKCN11W242	Reuters/Ipsos States of the Nation: Clinton leads in Florida	"
By Maurice Tamman
| NEW YORK
NEW YORK Democrat Hillary Clinton has pulled ahead of Republican rival Donald Trump in the traditional battleground state of Florida
column2: strengthening her position in the race for the White House
column3: the Reuters/Ipsos States of the Nation project showed ahead of the pair's first presidential debate on Monday night.If the election were held on Monday
column4: Clinton would lead Trump in the Electoral College by 259 to 191
column5: with an 88 percent chance of reaching the 270 needed to win
column6: according to the project's results.The project
column7: based on a weekly online tracking poll of more than 15
column9: estimates state-by-state results that will drive the voting in the Electoral College
column10: the body that ultimately selects the president.The results marked the first upward swing in the project for Clinton in several weeks. The last release of the poll
column12: gave her a 61 percent chance of winning by a margin of about 14 Electoral College votes. The big difference now is that Florida
column14: favors Clinton 49 percentage points to Trump's 45 points

column1: Trump has also lost ground in New Mexico
column2: where he trails 47 points to 38 points. Colorado and Nevada
column3: which had leaned toward Trump
column4: are now too close to call. Together
column5: those states represent another 20 Electoral College votes. Clinton lost ground in Oregon and Wisconsin
column6: which are also too close to call. They amount to 17 votes combined.As many as 100 million viewers have been estimated for Monday evening's debate at Hofstra University in New York state's Long Island

column1: Whether that high interest translates into a higher turnout on Election Day on Nov. 8 remains to be seen. A higher turnout would likely benefit Clinton
column2: while the opposite would benefit Trump
column3: according to Reuters/Ipsos polling
column4: whose latest estimate is for a moderate turnout.Trump's easiest path to victory would depend on a surge in turnout among white Republicans and lower-than-expected turnout among minority Democrats
column5: according to the project. In that scenario
column6: several Clinton-leaning states could flip. Florida
column10: Wisconsin and North Carolina would lean toward the Republican.

column1: The States of the Nation results came as Clinton's standing in national opinion polls have seen a small bounce in recent days. A separate Reuters/Ipsos national tracking poll released on Friday
column2: for example
column3: had her ahead by four points
column4: up from a near tie two weeks ago.  (Editing by Richard Valdmanis and Richard Chang)"

column1: By Steve Holland
| NEW YORK
NEW YORK (This story corrects sixth paragraph to say Matt Schlapp was White House political director
column2: not deputy.)Dozens of former appointees of the administration of former President George W. Bush announced their support for Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump on Sunday in a bid for party unity ahead of Trump's first debate with Democrat Hillary Clinton.The Bush family and many connected to it remain cool to Trump. Former President George H.W. Bush reportedly plans to vote for Clinton in the Nov. 8 election while his Jeb
column3: a former Trump rival
column4: has said he will not vote for Clinton or Trump. George W. Bush has avoided the presidential race while helping raise money for Republican congressional candidates.But a number of former Bush appointees have decided to endorse Trump
column5: the New York businessman who is in a tight race with Clinton and is to debate her one-one-one at Hofstra University on Monday night in Hempstead
column6: New York.

column1: Fifty former Bush appointees were on a list of people described as founding members of a coalition of Bush alumni supportive of Trump. The list was provided by a Republican official close to the Trump campaign.The list included former White House press secretary Ari Fleischer

column3: who is chairman of the American Conservative Union.Thompson
column4: in a statement
column5: explained his decision to be on the list.

column1: Americans want to trust our leaders again

column3: growing our economy
column4: defending our nation from terrorism
column5: and respecting the voters enough to be straight-forward and honest with them

column8: but many establishment figures remain skeptical about him
column9: such as Ohio Governor John Kasich. (Reporting By Steve Holland; Editing by Robert Birsel and Bill Trott)"

6	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-canada-idUSKCN11W0BC	Canada works to counter protectionist mood of U.S. campaign	"
By David Ljunggren
| OTTAWA

OTTAWA Canadian diplomats are fanning out across the United States to talk up the benefits of trade with state and local leaders and counter what senior officials see as a worrying mood of protectionism swirling through the U.S. election campaign.Amid voter anger about the supposed harm done by international trade deals
column2: both Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump and Democratic rival Hillary Clinton have talked about altering the three-nation North American Free Trade Agreement. That could have calamitous results for Canada
column3: which sends 75 percent of all its exports to the United States.From trade forums in Kentucky
column4: California and Illinois addressing state legislators and small-business owners to meetings with mayors
column5: labor unions and interest groups
column6: a team of diplomats has gone coast to coast to explain how important Canada is as a trading partner.The diplomatic offensive comes amid concerns in Ottawa about both candidates
column7: who opinion show are in a tight race ahead of the Nov. 8 election.Trump has talked about renegotiating the NAFTA treaty with Canada and Mexico to secure more favorable terms for the United States. But he has also said he would revive TransCanada Corp's cross-border Keystone XL pipeline project
column8: which Democratic President Barack Obama's administration blocked over environment concerns. Clinton has said she opposes Keystone XL.Current and former government officials in Ottawa said a Clinton presidency posed its own challenges for Canada.They see the Democrat as tough on trade and more hawkish than Democratic President Barack Obama
column9: who quickly struck up a warm relationship with Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau. While tough talk on trade has occurred in previous U.S. election campaigns
column10: ""there is an undercurrent and a mood here which is concerning me
column12: Canada's ambassador to Washington.A Clinton campaign representative declined to comment when asked about her approach to Canada if she were elected. Trump's campaign could not immediately be reached for comment.MacNaughton
column13: who took up the job in March
column15: Colorado Springs and Boston and plans trips to Massachusetts

column1: An embassy spokeswoman said diplomats were intensifying their outreach effort and doing more events than usual. At every meeting
column2: they hand out tip sheets showing Canada is the top export destination for 35 U.S. states and that 9 million U.S. jobs depend on trade with Canada.'PRETTY DIFFICULT SITUATIONS'

column1: Trudeau will not say which candidate he favors
column2: stressing he is happy to work with whomever U.S. voters elect. But his center-left Liberals have more policies in common with U.S. Democrats. Elected last October
column3: he and Obama have become close
column4: exchanging visits to each other's countries. ""Some of the issues that we are going to be facing will be very much the same regardless of who wins. ... I think we have to prepare to deal with some pretty difficult situations on the trade front
column5: said MacNaughton
column6: adding that some Americans had little idea about the size of the U.S. trading relationship with Canada.

column1: Roland Paris
column2: who served as Trudeau's foreign policy adviser until late June
column3: said Trump had tapped into some very strong anti-trade sentiment.""Those feelings aren't going away any time soon ... we may be heading into some protectionist headwinds
column4: even with a Hillary Clinton presidency
column5: he said. Trump and Clinton also oppose a proposed Pacific trade deal that could benefit Canada. One person with day-to-day knowledge of the U.S.-Canada trade file also predicted strains over Canadian exports of softwood lumber
column6: as well as Canada's system of protection for its dairy industry
column7: which U.S. producers strongly dislike.MILITARY SPENDING

column1: Another potential area for concern is Canada's defense spending
column2: which is 0.98 percent of gross domestic product
column3: far below the 2 percent commitment agreed on by NATO members.MacNaughton said that in his talks with Republicans and Democrats
column4: both had raised the issue of ""U.S. allies stepping up to the plate"" in military terms.Trump stirred concerns among allies and even some Republicans earlier this year by saying he would decide whether to come to the aid of Baltic NATO allies in the event of Russian aggression only after reviewing if they ""have fulfilled their obligations to us.""Former Canadian diplomat Colin Robertson
column5: who had several postings in the United States
column6: also predicted hard discussions with Clinton administration officials over defense.""We will be circled because we are at 0.98 percent
column8: vice president of the Canadian Global Affairs Institute.That may not sit well with Trudeau's government
column9: which is pledging to run large budget deficits for at least the next five years to fund investment in infrastructure and social programs.A government source said Canada had taken part in a number of high-profile NATO missions and was ready to push back on demands to increase spending in the military.""We're quite prepared and proud to stand up on our record and explain why there might be a discrepancy between numbers ... and our actual contribution
column11: who asked not to be identified given the sensitivity of the topic. (Reporting by David Ljunggren; Editing by Peter Cooney)"

column1: 7	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-poll-debate-idUSKCN11W0AS	Debates to help half of U.S. voters decide between Clinton
column2: Trump: poll	"

column1: By Ginger Gibson
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON Half of America's likely voters will rely on the presidential debates to help them make their choice between Republican Donald Trump and Democrat Hillary Clinton in the Nov. 8 election
column2: according to a Reuters/Ipsos poll released on Monday.The results show the stakes for the White House rivals as they prepare to face off on Monday at Hofstra University in Long Island
column3: New York
column4: for their first of three one-on-one debates
column5: a prime-time TV spectacle expected to draw a Super Bowl-sized audience of 100 million Americans.Some 50 percent of likely voters think the debates will help inform their decision of whom to support
column6: including 10 percent who say they are not currently leaning either way
column7: according to the opinion poll. Some 39 percent said the debates will not help
column8: and 11 percent said they did not know how the debates would affect them.In a strong signal that most viewers will also be hoping the debates bring clarity
column9: some 72 percent of respondents said they want to see moderators point out when a candidate says something that is untrue. That included 73 percent of people who identified themselves as Trump supporters and 82 percent of those who said they back Clinton
column10: according to the results.""It helps the audience
column12: to recognize what's bull crap and what's real
column16: Michigan. ""It's easy for the candidates to quote a statistic and people accept it.""

column1: Clinton currently leads in most national polls and holds critical advantages in key swing states like Ohio and North Carolina. The latest Reuters/Ipsos poll finds Clinton leading Trump nationally by 4 percentage points.Clinton had seen her popularity dip in recent weeks after more questions arose about her family foundation and the use of a private email server while she was secretary of state.
NO"" TO NAME-CALLING
Many voters are hoping to see a relatively civilized debate
column2: after months of mutual attacks between Trump and Clinton on the campaign trail. Trump has called for Clinton to be jailed for her handling of emails as America's top diplomat. Clinton has accused Trump of racism and of being temperamentally unfit for the Oval Office.Of those polled
column3: 61 percent said they are not interested in those kinds of attacks.

column1: Quit picking on each other
column2: said Lisa Miller
column4: of St. Louis
column5: Missouri. ""This isn't a playground. Grow up and talk about your plan."" A plurality of likely voters want to hear both Clinton and Trump talk about jobs and the economy
column6: the poll found. ""I'll tell you with Donald Trump I want to see that he has rational answers to questions without name calling
column7: said Leven. ""I want to try to get beyond the political hocus pocus that both of them are doing and try to see who they really are.""The Reuters/Ipsos poll was conducted online in English in all 50 states. It included 2
column10: 337 people who were deemed to be likely voters due to their voting history
column11: registration status and stated intention to show up on Election Day. The poll has a credibility interval
column13: of 2 percentage points for all respondents and 3 percentage points for likely voters. (Reporting by Ginger Gibson and Chris Kahn; Editing by Richard Valdmanis and Leslie Adler)"

column1: 8	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-netanyahu-idUSKCN11V0Q6	Trump tells Netanyahu he would recognize Jerusalem as Israel's capital	"
By Alana Wise
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON U.S. Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump on Sunday told Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu that if elected
column2: the United States would recognize Jerusalem as the capital of Israel

column4: marking a potential dramatic shift in U.S. policy. During the meeting that lasted more than an hour at Trump Tower in New York

column8: including the United States. Most nations maintain embassies in Tel Aviv. Palestinians want East Jerusalem
